channel.title: [Tut] Adding a World Changing Box

item.title: [Tut] Adding a World Changing Box
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

Bad… Bad bad, baddd. BAD.

But I suppose I have no say here, my loader has a form pop up and ask you what world to load. There’s a list and a text box on it, either select something from the list or type in the world number you want, or type in the prefix —> see? Hehehe on error it loads the default world instead of crashing.

String url = defaultWorld; if(typed.equals("")) { int remInfo = selection.indexOf("http"); if(remInfo != -1) { url = selection.subString(remInfo); } } else if(typed.matches("[a-zA-Z]+[0-9]+")) { url = "http://" + typed + ".runescape.com/"; } else (typed.matches("[0-9][0-9]?[0-9]?")) { try { url = lookupAddress(Integer.parseInt(typed)); } catch(Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); } } loadGame(url);

Cleanish lookup code.

[code] public static String defaultWorld = “http://planet4.runescape.com/”;

public String lookupAddress(int i) {
    switch(i) {
        ...
        case 40: return "http://planet3.runescape.com/";
        case 41: return "http://planet4.runescape.com/";
        ...
        default: return defaultWorld;
    }
}[/code]

Read full topic

and I did add you on msn, im just hardly ever on it, more often im on the kaitnieks irc channel

You could just do:
if(serverSelect(ksdlfjd))
server = “sdfsd”;

But, still, it’s cleaner using select case.[/quote]

item.title: [Tut] Adding a World Changing Box
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

ok im feeling extra generous tonight, here is my code for autoupdating the world box, it hasnt failed me once since 340:

instructions:

you need a string in the client called worldnum, you can do with it what you want, you just need to declare it

you need to load the client line by line into a string array named clientline, so that my loops can flip through, if you dont understand these instructions, learn java and figure them out, dont ask

Pattern pattern3 = Pattern.compile("if\\(super\\.anInt\\d{1,4} == 1 && super\\.anInt\\d{1,4} >= \\w{1,2} - 15 && super\\.anInt\\d{1,4} < \\w\\d?\\)"); for (int x=0;x<clientline.length&&clientline[x]!=null; x++){//adds world switcher Matcher match2 = pattern3.matcher(clientline[x]); if(match2.find()){ clientline[x+5] = clientline[x+5]+"\n"+clientline[x]+"\n"+clientline[x+1].replace("0;","2;")+"\n"+clientline[x+2]; String[] result = clientline[x+1].trim().split("\\s"); for (int i=0;i<clientline.length&&clientline[i]!=null; i++) if(clientline[i].indexOf("if("+result[0]+" == 1)")>-1){ String[] password = clientline[i+3].trim().split("\\s"); clientline[i+10] = clientline[i+10]+"else\nif("+result[0]+" == 2)\n"; for (int z=1;z<10;z++) clientline[i+10] = ((clientline[i+10]+clientline[i+z]+"\n").replaceAll(password[0],"worldnum")).replaceAll("20\\)","3)"); clientline[i+10] = clientline[i+10]+"}"; clientline[i+5] = clientline[i+5].replace("0;","2;"); i = clientline.length; for (int y=0;y<clientline.length&&clientline[y]!=null; y++) if(clientline[y].indexOf("Username: ")>-1){ clientline[y+3] = clientline[y+3]+"\n"+ clientline[y].replaceAll("aString\\d{1,4}","worldnum").replaceAll("Username","World #").replaceAll("== 0\\)","== 2\\)")+ "\n"+clientline[y+3]; y = clientline.length; } } x = clientline.length; } }

have fun, and dont expect any more of the updater

Read full topic

item.title: [Tut] Adding a World Changing Box
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

newbiehacker:

I never worked out the enter thing lmao =\

its the huge if statements, copy the one for the username and change the variables like this (old deob, but youll figure it out):

if(anInt1236 == 1) { if(l1 == 8 && aString1046.length() > 0) aString1046 = aString1046.substring(0, aString1046.length() - 1); if(l1 == 9 || l1 == 10 || l1 == 13) anInt1236 = 0; //this is the code executed when enter is pressed, needs to be changed to 2 //so that it goes to the worldbox instead of 0, which is username if(flag) aString1046 += (char)l1; if(aString1046.length() > 20) aString1046 = aString1046.substring(0, 20); } //this is the added one below, above is for password if(anInt1236 == 2) { if(l1 == 8 && serverselect.length() > 0) serverselect = serverselect.substring(0, serverselect.length() - 1); if(l1 == 9 || l1 == 10 || l1 == 13) anInt1236 = 0; if(flag) serverselect+= (char)l1; if(serverselect.length() > 20)//you can change the number 20 from here and below to 3 serverselect= serverselect.substring(0, 2); }

hope that helped

item.title: [Tut] Adding a World Changing Box
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

[code]String[] worlds = {“world1prefix”, “world2prefix”,“world3prefix”};

private void changeWorldConnect(int idx) {
prefix = worlds[idx-1];
}[/code]

Though I wouldn’t ever have that in the client or extensions thereof. Stick it in the loader if you must.

edit: ppl has a point

item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

[quote=“moparisthebest, post:5, topic:480”]damn olie, thats a painful way of doing it, here is mine (its better :D):

public String worldprefix(int i){ switch (i){ /*free*/ case 1: return "ul2"; case 29: return "ul6"; case 32: return "ul1"; case 3: return "po3"; case 4: return "po4"; case 5: return "po5"; case 30: return "po7"; case 31: return "po8"; case 55: return "ch1"; case 57: return "ch3"; case 7: return "above2"; case 8: return "above3"; case 47: return "above5"; case 61: return "se1"; case 62: return "se2"; case 63: return "se3"; case 49: return "ams1"; case 50: return "ams2"; case 51: return "ams3"; case 52: return "ams4"; case 15: return "uk2"; case 16: return "uk3"; case 17: return "tor1"; case 37: return "tor3"; case 13: return "nl3"; case 14: return "nl4"; case 19: return "cet1"; case 20: return "cet2"; case 21: return "cet5"; case 25: return "cet6"; case 56: return "cet4"; case 33: return "at1"; case 34: return "at2"; case 35: return "at3"; case 38: return "planet1"; case 39: return "planet2"; case 40: return "planet3"; case 45: return "planet5"; case 43: return "sl11"; case 72: return "sl1"; case 73: return "sl2"; case 74: return "sl3"; case 75: return "sl4"; case 76: return "sl5"; case 10: return "jolt7"; case 11: return "jolt8"; case 67: return "jolt10"; case 68: return "jolt11"; case 80: return "jolt1"; case 81: return "jolt2"; case 82: return "jolt3"; case 85: return "ny1"; case 86: return "ny2"; case 87: return "ny4"; case 90: return "ny7"; case 92: return "nl9"; case 93: return "mi1"; case 94: return "mi2"; case 95: return "mi3"; case 96: return "mi4"; case 97: return "mi5"; case 101: return "at7"; case 102: return "at8"; case 106: return "uk9"; case 107: return "au1"; case 108: return "au2"; case 109: return "au3"; /*members*/ case 2: return "ul4"; case 26: return "ul5"; case 6: return "po6"; case 42: return "po2"; case 58: return "ch4"; case 59: return "ch5"; case 60: return "ch6"; case 9: return "above4"; case 48: return "above6"; case 64: return "se4"; case 66: return "se6"; case 53: return "ams5"; case 54: return "ams6"; case 23: return "uk4"; case 24: return "uk5"; case 71: return "uk7"; case 18: return "tor2"; case 22: return "nl1"; case 27: return "nl5"; case 28: return "nl6"; case 36: return "at4"; case 44: return "at6"; case 41: return "planet4"; case 46: return "planet6"; case 70: return "sl10"; case 77: return "sl6"; case 78: return "sl7"; case 79: return "sl8"; case 12: return "jolt9"; case 69: return "jolt12"; case 83: return "jolt4"; case 84: return "jolt5"; case 88: return "ny5"; case 89: return "ny6"; case 91: return "ny8"; case 98: return "mi6"; case 99: return "mi7"; case 100: return "mi8"; case 103: return "at9"; case 104: return "at10"; case 110: return "au4"; case 111: return "au5"; case 112: return "au6"; } return "jolt7"; }[/quote]

Nice. That’s a better way of doing things.
